respondent.name: DAVID DiGUGLIELMO, SUPERINTENDENT, STATE CORRECTIONAL INSTITUTION AT : GRATERFORD.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: We'll hear argument in Pace against the -- the warden. Mr. Wycoff.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Well, he -- he had a prior round of hearings at the State level on these same claims, did he not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: I know, but the substance of it, saying it isn't fair to give me life without parole 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 because of what happened, I didn't understand the plea - - he raised that in State court before.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE O'CONNOR
speakers.text: And he -- he essentially wants to relitigate the substance of those previous claims.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- of both claims was, however he dressed it up in -- in due process, that I wasn't told at the time of my sentencing that life meant 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 life without parole. That was the essence, the core of his complaint the first time around, wasn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the -- but the essence of it was I wasn't told that life meant I would never get out of prison.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Both times.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Wycoff, are you taking the position that this -- that Artuz -- I thought, frankly, that Artuz had classified within properly filed timely filed and then had a footnote, and it says that there might be some exceptions to a timely filing rule - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- rule. And they're not taking a position about that. But you quickly said this time limitation falls under the procedural bar label.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, it depends on what the exceptions are. If -- if -- as -- here I understand there are three exceptions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And they're all spelled out in the statute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Yes. And -- and if you do not plead any of those exceptions when you -- when you file, it seems to me it's not properly filed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't care what the Pennsylvania law is. I mean, it -- it seems to me if you have a statute that says it's untimely unless one of these three exceptions apply, and -- and you -- you simply file and you don't say -- and it's clearly out of time without one of the exceptions, and you simply file and don't say but this exception applies, it seems to me that's not properly filed, whatever the rule in -- in Pennsylvania was.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you haven't pleaded any of them, none at all. You just file it - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- several years out of time. You -- you make no assertion that any one of the -- of the three specific exceptions applies. I don't see how that could possibly be considered properly filed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Ah, that -- that's your theory that -- that -- 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Unless it can be rejected by the clerk - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you haven't made the claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What -- what does the Pennsylvania court -- law now say with respect to claim- by-claim pleading of the exceptions?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Claim by claim?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: This problem couldn't arise again in Pennsylvania, couldn't it, because they have a 1 - year statute of limitations? So there would be no way that you could be untimely filing within the 1 year that you have to go to Federal court. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It can? How could it - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: You do. I thought AEDPA you had to file within a year.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And then if you miss the year, you're out of luck. Period.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I see. So in other words, he -- his conviction is final.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: 60 days runs after his final conviction and then between the 60th day and the 365th day, he has discovered his Brady claim and has not got 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 into court within 60 days.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And Justice Scalia's question -- I'm interested in this. It couldn't arise. That is, a person who files his State collateral petition more than 365 days after the finality of the State court direct review, that person is out of luck under anybody's interpretation because more than a year has passed since it became final, i.e., the State direct review. Am I right or wrong about that? That's what's puzzling me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But AEDPA -- it doesn't say 1 year and that's it. AEDPA has exceptions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The exemptions still could be the problem.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Yes. We would have to breathe life back into the stay and abey - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But let me ask you this. Returning to our earlier discussion about pleading a specific exemption - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- are there States, do you know, where that is not required and the State court will go through the exceptions even if you haven't pled them?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but I thought you said Pennsylvania law had changed now.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But my -- my question is do you know if there are other States where they say, we don't care if you plead these - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- exemptions specifically or not? We're going to look through it and find it for ourselves.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And you say that if that's the case, you can file a -- a State -- a State claim that is plainly no good and until the State court finally gets around to -- to telling you that it's no good, your - - your AEDPA claim is tolled.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that's, in -- in effect, saying that there is no -- that the properly filed, given the Pennsylvania procedure, does not include timely filed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But -- but you have just said that the -- the court will look on its own to see if there are these exceptions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So that there would be no 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 case of an untimely filing in this period when the court was -- even if you raised no exception, was going through them.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There would be no case in which an untimely filing would be included in properly filed because the very fact that the court itself would go through the petition to look for exceptions would take it out of the category.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But the -- the difference was that Artuz ranked timely filing as an ingredient of properly filed, and you say but not in Pennsylvania the way it's set up. Timely filing is not an ingredient of properly filed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But don't -- don't you have a -- a -- sort of a second prong to -- to your response? And I -- I wanted to get into this. You -- you have said Pennsylvania will let you file even though ultimately it, you know, may well determine that you -- you were out of 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 time and you don't fall within any of the exceptions. Well, that's -- that's an answer. I'm not sure it's a strong enough answer to respond to Artuz. But I thought you had a second part to the answer, and I thought your second part to the answer was in that kind of situation, the Third Circuit practice, the Third Circuit rule is that unless we go through the Pennsylvania process, even if we know from day one that we're out of time, we think we have a -- an excuse, but even though we -- we think from day one we're out of time, unless we exhaust the Pennsylvania process, they will throw us out for nonexhaustion. And the reason they will throw us out from nonexhaustion, as opposed to going directly to the question whether there is an excuse for nonexhaustion, is because Pennsylvania will actually let us litigate this - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- and not determine it as a threshold matter. So -- so your answer, as I understand it, is Pennsylvania let's you litigate it, and the Third Circuit requires you to litigate it so that the only reasonable thing for us to do is to litigate it even if you may say in the abstract it's a purely threshold time question. And for that reason, there should be tolling. Isn't that 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 your argument?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: This is putting such a -- I mean, the system is not going to work. It -- it's a rare State system that has an absolute statute of limitation with no exceptions. You're almost going to have to inquire into exceptions. So you're saying this is a way to avoid -- avoid AEDPA endlessly, just keep filing claims that are out of time, and until the court finally gets around to saying it's out of time, your -- your AEDPA time is tolled - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- by which time you file another one that's clearly out of time. And until that one is resolved -- I -- this couldn't be what AEDPA was - - was meant to establish.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: And -- and if you're tempted 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 to answer, well, people want to get out so they're not going to sit around forever, then we'd ask you what about the death cases.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'm not sure that would apply to other States.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Under your rule that filing is sufficient, are there any instances of -- of frivolous petition where your rule would not apply? 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, then Justice Scalia's prediction is -- is right. You just keep filing and filing.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Suppose you lost on that one. Suppose that you wanted some kind of a -- suppose that the majority wanted a standard that would prevent absolutely frivolous filings on the basis of -- of statute of limitations. Would you -- what standard would -- what - - what's our choice of standards there? Could we -- one, obviously, that the prisoner has to be in good faith. Another could be he has to be in good faith and there has to be a reasonable argument that it hasn't run. Maybe there are others that you've thought of.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Try -- try this simple rule. Where you're dealing with a statute of limitations that has exceptions, it's not properly filed if you do not assert the existence of one of those exceptions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why -- why not? We make up a lot of stuff. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought the whole purpose of AEDPA was -- was to prevent delay. I mean, that's - - that's what's -- it seems to me counter-intuitive about the position you're -- you're urging upon us. Here is a statute that was meant to stop these things from dragging on endlessly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And you tell us don't worry about these things dragging on endlessly.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's unrealistic if the States allow you to file a lot of stuff. You're -- you're saying the only way the States can stop this thing from going on and on and on is to adopt an absolute rigid statute of limitations, no exceptions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Give me another way.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Oh, but if it takes a year a later, then we - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Then you just repeat the process one step backward.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: What about a -- a rule requiring good faith or reasonable argument in death cases? In all the other cases, there's no incentive to do this endless filing, and in death cases, there is. So in those death cases, we would insist that it is not properly filed if it's out of time unless the prisoner in good faith and with a plausible argument, a reasonable argument thought it was in time.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you think that's a reasonable interpretation of properly filed and -- and what I proposed to you is not a reasonable interpretation of properly filed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: How can you -- how can you tease that elaborate system out of -- out of the words properly filed but you cannot tease out of it - - 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- simply showing on its face that there's either an absolute statute or that one of the exceptions to the statute exists?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, I don't think it actually -- I mean, in -- I think they're about equal, aren't they, in respect to language? And the argument against the other one is that prisoners are going to get mixed up about it. They -- they don't know exactly what they're supposed to put. The argument against the one I proposed is it adds complexity of decision-making. Sort of between the two, it's rather hard to see.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: They each have their problems.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The circumstances included the fact that he sat on this thing for 3 years. He could have brought it 3 years earlier, couldn't he?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: The claim, yes, that's right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So -- when -- when you -- when you fold that into the circumstances, it doesn't seem to 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 me an overwhelming case for equitable tolling.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: -- take a whole lot to figure out that you have a claim where your lawyer told you - - you weren't going up for life and it turned out you were sent up for life.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, what does it take if - - can a 17-year-old figure that something has gone wrong here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You may. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Eisenberg.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but if we accept your position, it seems to me that State prisoners are going to have to go but once to Federal court and then they're -- they're going to run into an exhaustion requirement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, we're --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- we're assuming a late- discovered claim that's within AEDPA.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It -- it's my -- I still have a feeling that this is a limited universe. Now, my reason for thinking that is that the Federal statute says you 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 have to file within a year of -- and then it lists four dates. And the middle two are special new cases, unusual probably. The first one and the fourth one are the important ones. The first one is final in the State courts, your first round, and the fourth one is newly discovered evidence. Now, my guess is most States also allow you for collateral -- to file collateral relief in those two circumstances. And in most States probably you get nearly a year from the same kind of event. So if you go after the year, you're out of luck in Federal court. If you're within the year, you're probably okay for the State. But there are a few States that have -- maybe Pennsylvania - - just 60 days from one of the events, newly discovered evidence, but a year for the Federal. So we're talking about people who file between 2 and 12 months. That - - that must be a pretty limited class.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But have I got it right? Have I got this complicated thing right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Now, let's - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What do I do it in a State where there is a plausible close question of whether or not the successive petition is barred in the State court? And I interrupted Justice Breyer, but I -- I think it's along the same line.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But no -- there's still an exhaustion requirement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But isn't there a wrinkle to this? Isn't the wrinkle that even in cases in which you 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 and I might say patently he's going to be out of time if he goes back to Federal court, the Third Circuit is requiring him to go there anyway, go through the formality of formal exhaustion, if you will, before they'll consider it? And isn't that a basis at least for equitable tolling?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Right. MR> EISENBERG: with respect to understanding the -- the language of the statute. As to equitable tolling, however, the factual premise is wrong. It's not true that the Third Circuit forces the defendant to go back to State court no matter what. In fact - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Okay. Help me -- help me out here because I -- I just don't remember well enough. I thought that's what Judge Giles was getting at when he said, you know, he would have been thrown if he hadn't gone through the State procedure. So help me out. Is that what he was getting at or not?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: If that means the petitioner was wrong, doesn't it also mean that Judge Giles is wrong, and if Judge Giles can't figure it out, isn't there a pretty good argument that the petitioner ought to get equitable tolling?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But -- but Judge Giles didn't understand it either.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: So far as this case is concerned, yes. And -- and so if Judge Giles got it wrong, isn't there a pretty good argument for equitable tolling when the petitioner gets it wrong?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But -- but this argument is not trying to decide for the States. This argument basically is if nobody can figure it out, including a Federal district judge, at least give me the benefit of the doubt with equitable tolling.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: But if he had gone into the Federal court he went into, and he had not gone through this State procedure, he would have been turfed out.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, answer that question - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: -- before you tell me what the consequence is.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, I mean, don't -- don't we have to take Judge Giles' statement as being a statement in good faith unless there is a pretty darned good reason not to?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. Let's suppose to get away from it -- can I go -- are you finished with equitable tolling because I want to go back to - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I -- I have a general question which is not Pennsylvania. I've looked up or got a rough idea of the statute of limitations for a first petition in many States, and most of them are a year or more. So there's no problem. But 11 have less than a year, and in particular, Oklahoma has 3 months apparently. And Oklahoma is -- a lot of death cases come out of Oklahoma. So what rule would -- where I have to have -- I focus on Oklahoma for the reason that I think this has bite only in death cases because I don't see why anybody would want to abuse the system except in a death case. But there are a lot there. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 Now, am I supposed to say in Oklahoma which has the 90 days but exceptions, that where somebody has filed a petition in State court, let's say, on the 180th day, and he thinks an exception applies, is he supposed to also run to Federal court and file a protective petition which could well have been dismissed on exhaustion grounds? What's he supposed to do and how is he supposed to know what to do? And one system that might work is Justice Scalia's idea.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Another that might work is - - is requiring in death cases that it be a -- a plausible ground or something like that. I want to know your opinion of how to deal with that circumstance.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Actually most prisoners are not represented, I don't think, at this stage. They -- they haven't a clue about the word exhaustion, and they haven't a clue about the statute of limitations. So they file a -- a paper in -- in the State court, and they say this roughly is what my problem is. Is that what happens, or are they all quite educated?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: I'm trying to get from you what is your opinion of a practical approach to this problem in Oklahoma, say.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask how you would handle a case that is a successive petition, a late -- a recently found claim, and the -- filed beyond the statute of limitations but the State has three exceptions to the 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400 statute, but it does not require that the -- the petitioner identify the exception in the petition? It just allows it for the judge to decide. Would there be tolling during the period in which the judge decided whether or not the petition was timely in your view?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And even if it takes a year or so to make that decision, you'd say no tolling.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And in all of those questions, you'd say there would be no tolling in order to find out whether it was timely or not. 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But what about the reasoning in Artuz that the application was -- if it turns out later it was timely, it would have been properly filed?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No, but if I understand you correctly, you're saying that even if it takes the judge 6 months to decide whether it was timely, if he ends up with the conclusion that it was not timely, there would be no tolling for that 6-month period.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why -- why are there thousands of cases in which noncapital defendants file this type of case? What -- what incentives do noncapital defendants have to drag it on?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: It seems -- it seems intuitive also that the prosecution's witnesses will be difficult to locate and so forth. Has -- has there been anything written about that, about prejudice to the prosecution from -- from delay, or is it just something we - - 1111 14th Street, NW Suite 400

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- we take judicial notice of?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, he also raised an -- an entirely different claim, didn't he? I mean, it goes to ultimately the same point, but he raised the claim that the court had not engaged in an adequate colloquy - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Right. But that -- the -- I mean, it's a different claim. The judge has an independent responsibility. It's not the lawyer's responsibility.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: That -- that may be, but it is a different claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: It is not the claim of ineffective assistance.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Just as a matter of curiosity, is the transcript of the plea colloquy still available?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And was there the constitutional violation he alleges?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: The irony of this whole proceeding is it seems to me it would be a lot easier to decide the merits of that claim if the transcript is available than to get into all these issues - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- we have today.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Of course, he's a 17-year-old without any learning in the law. He probably didn't realize there's any requirement that these things have to appear in the transcript. I mean, that's understandable.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Eisenberg.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Wycoff, you have about 4 minutes left.
